subject: Education
title: The 30-Million-Word Gap: Talk Matters
description: A 60-second lesson on The 30-Million-Word Gap: Talk Matters.

hook.text: By age 3, children from affluent families have heard 30 million more words than children from poor families.

buildup.text: Hart and Risley's famous 1995 study tracked families and found the word gap predicted academic achievement at age 9.

discovery.text: It's not just quantity â€” it's quality. Rich conversations with varied vocabulary build stronger language circuits.

twist.text: The study has been criticized for small sample size and class bias. But the core finding holds: talk builds brains.

climax.text: The word gap shows that education inequality begins at birth â€” long before children enter any school.

punchline.text: The biggest educational advantage isn't money. It's conversation.

quiz.question: What does the '30-million-word gap' refer to?
options: The number of books in libraries
The difference in words heard by children from different economic backgrounds
The size of a child's vocabulary
